abstract.text: An anchor that identifies a geographic location using latitude, longitude, and altitude data.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
geographic anchor
(also known as
location anchor
) identifies a specific area in the world that the app can refer to in an AR experience. As a user moves around the scene, the session updates a location anchor’s
based on the anchor’s
and the device’s compass heading.
ARKit aligns location anchors to an East-North-Up orientation, with its x- and z-axes matching the longitude and latitude directions. For more information, see
ARKit sets the anchor’s vertical position to the altitude you pass in to
. If you initialize a location anchor using
instead, ARKit sets the anchor’s altitude to ground level.
Location anchors are available only in geotracking sessions, and geotracking is available in specific areas; for more information, see
Location anchors consume data from Apple Maps called
localization imagery
(for more information, see

). As the user moves, the framework downloads localization imagery to refine the user’s precise geographic position. The amount of data the session requires depends on the user’s movement and distance they travel. To make the user aware of potential fees, you can notify the user of their data usage.
When an app creates a location anchor, it’s invisible to the user until the framework
populates
the anchor in the scene. When an anchor populates successfully, the session passes the anchor into the delegate’s
callback.
If ARKit fails to populate a location anchor, the session calls
to notify your delegate. A location anchor may fail to populate when:

The network is unavailable. If you create a location anchor without providing an altitude, ARKit defaults the altitude to ground level, and may query the server to check the topography at the anchor’s geographic coordinate. If the network is unavailable, ask the user to restore a connection by disabling Airplane Mode, enabling WiFi, or moving to a location that provides service. If the network is available but slow, an altitude query response may be delayed. Consider pausing a navigation or presenting visual feedback for the anchor’s tentative placement, such as by displaying a status indicator.

The location anchor is too far from the user. If users can create location anchors in your app, let them know to position the coordinates of each anchor within 0.05 degrees (~5 kilometers) of themselves and their device.
The server prevents the location anchor’s position, such as in a large body of water.

abstract.text: Integrate hardware sensing features to produce augmented reality apps and games.
An object that specifies the position and orientation of an item in the physical environment.
A matrix encoding the position, orientation, and scale of the anchor relative to the world coordinate space of the AR session the anchor is placed in.
Support for custom anchor subclasses.
The coordinate system’s y-axis is parallel to gravity, its x- and z-axes are oriented to compass heading, and its origin is the initial position of the device.
An anchor that identifies a geographic location using latitude, longitude, and altitude data.
Options for setting a location anchor’s altitude.
Vertical distance, in meters, between this anchor and sea level.
Vertical distance, in meters, between this anchor and sea level.
A record of the source from which an altitude came.
The lattitude and longitude of the anchor’s geographic location.
Initializes a location anchor with the given coordinate and altitude.
Initializes a named location anchor with the given coordinates and altitude.
Initializes a named location anchor with the given coordinates and altitude.
Initializes a new location anchor with the given coordinates.
Initializes a location anchor with the given coordinate and altitude.
Initializes a named location anchor with the given coordinates.
A configuration that tracks locations with GPS, map data, and a device’s compass.
Tells the delegate that one or more anchors have been added to the session.
Tells the delegate that one or more anchors have been removed from the session.
An interface for objects that track the location of real-world objects or locations.
Track specific geographic areas of interest and render them in an AR experience.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
